lines.text: Hey, how you doin', buddy? As you can see, we eat very well around here. Hey, on the up and up, if there's anything you might need, I'm the guy to see around here. If I don't have it, I can get it for you.
Beat it.
Oh, excuse me. I didn't recognize you, General.
I drink to you, and to the American Army.
How long ago were you drinking to the Third Reich?
I do not like the Germans.
You don't like me, either, but you're drinking with me.
I was kind of surprised to see you in our outfit.
You and me both.
I haven't had time to check your papers. Where'd you transfer from?
The outfit I came from was a real dilly. There was a general, a major, two captains, two lieutenants, and me. There's a squad for you, buddy-o.
Sounds like a court martial board.
Hey, Corby, what's the matter with you? Can't you forget about that loot? You're in a church.
This ain't a church no more, Sergeant. And besides, even if it was, so what?
Well it used to be, J.J. You oughtta have respect for things that used to be.
What are you buckin' for chaplain or something? I got respect, Sergeant. Plenty. But its not for somebody I can't see.

[after the squad is fired on by a German machine gun]
You guys are covered here, but walk carefully beyond this point.
Walk? Are you out of your mind? I'm gonna dig a subway.
But Sergeant, you don't understand. I was sent to clerk-typist school. That's all I've ever done in the army was type!
Man, we're gonna give you on the job training.
What's up, Sergeant?
Take this man over to that foxhole next to Reese and teach him how to shoot.

[Larkin hands him Driscoll's brand new rifle]
With this here? It might get dirty.

[after the failed attempt on the pillbox]
How close did you get?
Two hundred yards.
How'd it happen?
Mine field.
Henshaw?
Yeah. He tripped a mine. He was carrying a torch. It lit up the whole countryside. Put us right on the block.
Were you right?
How the hell do I know?
Reese! Who gave the order for that attempt on the pillbox? You hear me? Who gave the order?
I did, sir.

You had orders to stay here on the ridge and hold it. You knew that! What about Kalinsky? What about the man you left in the field? And you say you gave the order, huh? Reese, you're a private, you don't give orders, you *take* them!
Why you no like Homer?
You got no business up here. When the Krauts come, they'll capture you and pull your fingernails. Then you'll tell them everything they want to know.
No!

[fake telephone conversation with "headquarters" to fool the Germans listening in]
Uh - Hi. Temple Red to - uh - Abel 6. This... This is Lt. Driscoll - the - uh - the entertainment officer.
About the morale, sir, it's been rather low. Uh - the main complaint seems to be about the evening movie.
Y-Yes, sir. I've had to show 'Road to Morocco' five evenings now in a row, sir.
Well, the men are beginning to be a little surly, sir.
Yes, sir. They know all the lines.

[fake telephone conversation with "headquarters" to fool the Germans listening in]
Temple Red. This is Lt Driscoll.
Wh- Don't send them up here. Sir, I have five men in each foxhole now. I don't have room for anymore, sir.
Have you tried Charlie company, sir?
Oh, I see. Well, sir, there's still a war going on in Japan, you know, sir, you might send them over there.
Oh, they're supposed to taste like potato soup?
We've got nothing but vacancies in this hotel.

[after PVT Driscoll crashes his jeep near the front lines, only to have it commandeered by the platoon sergeant, SFC Pike. Without a ride back to the relative safety of Division Headquarters, Driscoll is instantly transformed into a frontline combat troop - albeit untrained]
Don't worry about Major Winston. He'll be mighty happy and proud when he hears you've volunteered for combat duty.
But sergeant, you don't understand! I was sent to clerk-typist school. That's all I've ever done in the Army... was learn to type.
Man, we're gonna give you on-the-job training.

[checking on Driscoll's training]
How we doing?
Oh, splendid, Sergeant. He still can't hit anything, but he loads like a genius.

[fake telephone conversation with "headquarters" to fool the Germans listening in]
We'll certainly be on the look out for it, sir.
A Pfc, you say?
With a load of typewriters in the back?
Well if we see him, we'll contact you sir.
